H0.text: Miles are the units that astronomers most often use for the distance between Earth and Proxima Centauri, the closest star to the Sun.

H1.text: Meters are the units that astronomers most often use for the distance between Earth and Proxima Centauri, the closest star to the Sun.

H2.text: Light years are the units astronomers most often use for the distance between Earth and Proxima Centauri, the closest star to the Sun.

H3.text: Astronomical units are the units astronomers most often use for the distance between Earth and Proxima Centauri, the closest star to the Sun.

A4.text: The light-year is most often used when expressing distances to stars and other distances on a galactic scale, especially in non-specialist contexts and popular science publications.

A5.text: The unit most commonly used in professional astronomy is the parsec (symbol: pc, about 3.26 light-years).

A6.text: Proxima Centauri is located 4.25 light-years (1.3 parsecs) away.

A7.text: Proxima Centauri is 4.2465 light-years (1.3020 pc; 268,550 AU) from the Sun.
